body: my understanding is that the current default implementation for this event type uses the `downstream message sender` implementation to send such events. this sender timeouts if the peer does not acknowledge receiving the message. does this solve the problem? am trying to understand how i can approach this

@Alfusainey this is not about about timing out the sending, i.e. timing out while waiting for the broker's disposition frame. This is about how long the broker should keep the message in its queue, i.e. setting the message's *ttl* property accordingly ...

issue.title: [#1714] Set TTL for connection event messages.
issue.body:
fixes #1714

-  I placed the TTL config parameter in the `ClientConfigProperties` since protocol adapters connect to the messaging network to forward the `connection event` downstream. 
- I  currently set a default TTL value of 5 secs. Users can change the default  value  to any non-negative value by changing the corresponding config property.

@sophokles73 I was thinking of allowing  the  option  to set the value to `-1` if  a connection event message should be  keep in the broker (forever) until  it is consumed. WDYT? maybe this value would make a more sensible default?

Signed-off-by: Alfusainey Jallow <alf.jallow@gmail.com>

issue.title: Set time-to-live on (dis)connectedTtd event messages
issue.body:
The event messages sent from a protocol adapter when a device (un)subscribes for command messages currently get no `ttl` ("time-to-live") property set.

This could mean that these event messages get stored for an unnecessarily long period in the broker, especially if the northbound application isn't interested in these events.

For time-constrained command subscriptions (with "time-til-disconnect"/`ttd` property), we could set the `ttl` to the `ttd` value.
For other subscriptions we could use a configurable value (configured globally/on the tenant level).

issue.title: Error sending "Connection Event" event messages
issue.body:
When configuring Connection Events with producer "events" (instead of "logging"), so that event messages are sent, there is an exception sending the event if the tenant isn't configured in a specific way.

Sending the events only works if the tenant has a `maxTtl` configured (with value other than -1).
Otherwise there is either a NPE (if no resourselimits are configured) or a NumberFormatException (if `maxTtl` isn't set to another value than -1).
````
MQTT17:38:45.343 [vert.x-eventloop-thread-3] WARN  o.e.h.a.m.i.VertxBasedMqttProtocolAdapter - failed to send connection event for client [clientId: d93938c0-ac22-48f4-967c-4670ee68470e]
MQTTjava.lang.NullPointerException: null
MQTT	at org.eclipse.hono.service.monitoring.AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.lambda$sendNotificationEvent$0(AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.java:87)
MQTT	at io.vertx.core.Future.lambda$compose$3(Future.java:368)
MQTT	at io.vertx.core.impl.FutureImpl.dispatch(FutureImpl.java:105)
MQTT	at io.vertx.core.impl.FutureImpl.onComplete(FutureImpl.java:83)
MQTT	at io.vertx.core.Future.compose(Future.java:364)
MQTT	at io.vertx.core.Future.compose(Future.java:336)
MQTT	at org.eclipse.hono.service.monitoring.AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.sendNotificationEvent(AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.java:76)
MQTT	at org.eclipse.hono.service.monitoring.AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.connected(AbstractMessageSenderConnectionEventProducer.java:45)
MQTT	at org.eclipse.hono.service.AbstractProtocolAdapterBase.sendConnectedEvent(AbstractProtocolAdapterBase.java:1083)
````

(relates to #1714).
